speaker: Neil
text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Neil.

speaker: Rob
text: And hello. I'm Rob.

speaker: Neil
text: So Rob, you are a man who enjoys travel. What’s the furthest journey you’ve ever made?

speaker: Rob
text: Well, I have been to the other side of the world. I've been to Australia, New Zealand – so from London that's a very long way.

speaker: Neil
text: And how was it?

speaker: Rob
text: Well, it was pretty boring really and quite cramped on the aeroplane – but I loved it when I got there.

speaker: Neil
text: So how would you feel about a journey of 56 million kilometres that took around nine months?

speaker: Rob
text: Right. I'd have to travel Business Class, I think - lots of movies and a very comfortable seat!

speaker: Neil
text: Well, that’s how long it would take to get to the planet Mars and this programme is all about the women who want to be the first to set foot on the red planet. First, though, today’s question, which is about the size of Mars. Is it …

speaker: Neil
text: a)    Bigger than Earth

speaker: Neil
text: b)    About the same size as Earth, or

speaker: Neil
text: c)    Smaller than Earth

speaker: Rob
text: I’m pretty sure I know this. It’s bigger than Earth, much bigger I think.

speaker: Neil
text: Well, we’ll find out if you’re right at the end of the programme. It’s been 40 years since NASA first recruited women to be astronauts. Today, a third of the people who work at NASA are women.

speaker: Rob
text: Yes, and 2016 was the first year that there were an equal number of women and men joining as astronaut trainees.

speaker: Neil
text: Equality is slowly coming but only men have had the opportunity to walk on the Moon, although that was over 45 years ago. Karen Nyberg is one of NASA’s current astronauts. In a recent BBC News feature she talked about her hopes. When did she join the astronaut programme?

speaker: selecteda realistic possibilityunfortunate
text: When I was selected as an astronaut in the year 2000 I thought that that might be a realistic possibility, that we would be the ones, the next to go to the Moon. So it's unfortunate that we weren't.

speaker: Neil
text: When did she become an astronaut?

speaker: selectedSelected'
text: Well, she said that she was selected in 2000. 'Selected' means chosen.

speaker: selecteda realistic possibility
text: At that time, when she was selected, she thought going to the Moon would be a realistic possibility. So she thought that it wasn’t just a dream, but something that could happen. There was a good chance it would happen.

speaker: unfortunateunfortunate'
text: However, she was disappointed because that opportunity didn’t arrive at that time. She describes that as being unfortunate. In this sense 'unfortunate' means unlucky. If you use this adjective it means you are disappointed about something, but you do perhaps understand the reason for it.

speaker: Neil
text: So far, a woman hasn’t had the opportunity to step on the Moon. These days Mars is the big target for space travel. There are many problems to overcome, but could it, should it be a woman who is the first person to take that step?

speaker: Rob
text: Absolutely, why not? On a mission to Mars there would be need for many different kinds of specialists. We tend to think of astronauts as spaceship pilots, but really I think they are much more like scientists, carrying out different experiments.

speaker: aspectsaspects
text: If we are going to set up a base on Mars, one thing that would be very important is to try to find a way of growing food. For that you need people with skills in those areas. One person with those skills is Gioia Massa, a Life Science project manager for NASA. Now you would think that being a top scientist she would be brilliant at all areas or aspects of the job, but she told BBC News that it wasn’t always the case. What two aspects does she mention she wasn’t good at?

speaker: aspectsmath strengthstrength
text: There certainly were aspects where I was challenged, you know. I wasn't as great in math as some of my colleagues, my handwriting is terrible. So there are things that are not my strength. But then I fell in love with plants and plants were my strength, I really learned and focused on that.

speaker: Neil
text: So Rob, what did she have problems with?

speaker: mathMath'math'
text: Well, she said that she wasn’t good at math. 'Math' is a North American English word for what in British English, we call maths. Both words mean mathematics, so 'math' in American English, 'maths' in British English.

speaker: Neil
text: She also said that her handwriting is terrible!

speaker: Rob
text: Mind you, if her handwriting was really terrible, maybe nobody would be able to read her bad maths!

speaker: strengthsstrengths
text: Good point! So handwriting and maths aren’t or weren’t her strengths. They are not what she is good at. What are her strengths?

speaker: strengths
text: Well, the thing she is good at, her real strengths are working with plants, so that’s what she concentrated on.

speaker: strengths
text: Right. Well, let’s see if one of your strengths is the knowledge of the planets. Today’s quiz question was: Is Mars…

speaker: strengths
text: a)    Bigger than Earth

speaker: strengths
text: b)    About the same size as Earth

speaker: strengths
text: c)    Smaller than Earth

speaker: strengths
text: What did you say Rob?

speaker: Rob
text: I said that it was bigger, much bigger.

speaker: Neil
text: And the answer, I'm afraid to say, is that Mars is smaller than Earth, much smaller in fact.

speaker: selected
text: Oh, well, I guess I won’t be selected to be an astronaut any time soon!

speaker: selected'
text: Before we blast off out of here, let’s review the vocabulary we covered today. The first word was the one you just mentioned, 'selected', meaning chosen.

speaker: a realistic possibility'
text: Then we had the phrase, 'a realistic possibility' to describe something that has a good chance of happening, unlike my astronaut application!

speaker: unfortunate
text: Well, if you did become an astronaut, that would be unfortunate, our next word, for me at least.

speaker: Rob
text: Unfortunate, you mean disappointing for you?

speaker: Neil
text: Well, if you were up in space I wouldn’t have the pleasure of your company.

speaker: aspectsmath
text: Hashtag blushing. Our next word was 'aspects'meaning parts of something and then the Americanisation, 'math'.

speaker: strengthsstrengths
text: Which we call maths, or mathematics in British English. And finally we had 'strengths'. And maths certainly isn’t one of my strengths – it’s not something I’m good at.

speaker: strengths
text: But one of your strengths is saying nice things about people.

speaker: Neil
text: Hashtag double blush. Well, time for us to go – not to Mars, but to lunch! Just time to say you can also find us on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube, and of course on our website bbclearningenglish.com!  Thank you for joining us and goodbye!
